Award.AwardTitle: BREAD: Advancing the Cowpea Genome for Food Security
Award.AbstractNarration:
Cowpea, also known as black-eyed pea in the U.S.A., is a protein-rich grain-producing plant native to Africa. When cowpea is combined with starchy grains such as corn, sorghum or rice, the result is a complete source of major nutrients for energy and growth. It also provides protein-rich leaves and is used for animal feed. Cowpea is the primary source of protein for people in sub-Saharan Africa (SSA) where it is presently produced on over 20 million acres mainly by farmers with small land holdings. Its popularity is also due to its resilience to low rainfall and heat while also enriching the soil. Despite its relevance to food security in Africa and elsewhere, there has been relatively little basic research on cowpea. Advances in next generation sequencing technology have made it possible to "read" the genetic material of cowpea and decipher the instructions (genes and genetic variation) that ultimately provide for crop improvement. Producing an optimized reference genome sequence for cowpea is one of the main goals of this project, a feat that has been accomplished for human, mouse, cow and economically important crop plants such as corn, soybean, rice, bean and poplar. A broader purpose is to provide genetic resources to improve decision-making abilities within an existing network of African cowpea breeders. Breeders develop new varieties by making crosses between parents that carry favorable traits and selecting progeny containing favorable characteristics of both parents. This project will provide new materials for progeny selection in addition to knowledge that will facilitate the development of new cowpea varieties for increased food production.

Cowpea (Vigna unguiculata) is in the family Fabaceae, tribe Phaseoleae which includes other warm season legumes such as soybean, common bean and pigeon pea, as well as Vigna species adzuki bean and mung bean. Cowpea is diploid with 2n=22 chromosomes and a genome size of 620 Mb. Unlike other legumes, cowpea lacks a published reference genome. A highly fragmented draft genome sequence assembly has been available from previous work since 2011 (harvest-blast.org; harvest-web.org) and is derived from 60x short-reads combined with BAC-end and gene survey Sanger sequences. This project will elevate the sequence of cowpea to state-of-the art by: (1) adding long-read sequences and an optical map; (2) anchoring contigs to a recently developed genetic map containing 37,372 SNPs; and (3) improving browser access for the broader legume community. This will enable deeper utilization of cowpea germplasm for gene discovery and marker development, while providing a stronger foundation for the cowpea genetics and breeding community. Genetic intercrosses will be conducted to produce new pre-breeding lines that will theoretically carry optimal combinations of traits present within elite lines using a recently developed multi-parent advanced generation intercross (MAGIC) population based on eight parental lines. Marker-trait information, in the context of the genome sequence and haplotypes, will be disseminated for broad adoption of marker-informed breeding. This work is tightly linked to leading breeding programs in Burkina Faso, Ghana, Mozambique, Nigeria and Senegal through USAID Feed the Future and CGIAR Tropical Legumes projects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit.

The research utilized state-of-the-art technologies to develop and publish the first cowpea (Vigna unguiculata [L.] Walp.) reference genome assembly, including Pacific Biosciences long-read sequencing, Bionano optical mapping, ten high-density SNP-based genetic linkage maps and a novel method to stitch together a consensus assembly from multiple algorithms. This and assemblies from six additional accessions that were produced by Dovetail Genomics using HiC and Chicago methods, collectively representing the diversity of cultivated cowpeas (four from this project and two with a collaborator in China) were annotated by the DOE Phytozome team with all information provided through Phytozome. Two wild cowpeas were also sequenced and optically mapped, but were not yet at the stage of fully annotated assemblies by the end of this project. The gene annotations and genetic variations (SNPs, indels, inversions) identified from the initial pangenome defined by these accessions provide links between phenotype and genotype, enabling full exploitation of the rich cowpea germplasm for basic research and agricultural development. These high-quality genome sequences support comparative genomic studies with other legumes such as soybean and common bean, and other plants, revealing both shared and unique genome characteristics of the species. Additionally, genetic knowledge of a previously developed MAGIC population enabled new intercrosses for the development of more optimal genetic ideotypes, or “super-MAGIC” lines, which have been transferred to partners in West African breeding programs. Lastly, the genome knowledge developed in this project enabled well-informed choices of SNP markers that provided the basis of new breeding-friendly genotyping platforms, including a ~2500 SNP platform for the Excellence in Breeding Initiative.

Broader Impact.

Cowpea has figured prominently in the evolution of human civilization, and as such the story of cowpea reaches into history, anthropology, sociology and colonialism. Cowpea was one of the earliest plants to be domesticated, possibly the first legume. Cowpea is one of the most heat and drought-adapted of any legume crops, which is why it has been so well suited for drought-prone areas including sub-Saharan Africa, where it has been the primary source of protein for humans for several millennia. Cowpea moved across continents with early migrations of people from Africa to the Indian sub-continent and beyond, Westward across the Sahel, into ancient Greece and Rome, and across oceans throughout the Age of Exploration. There is still much to be revealed about the anthropological history of cowpea. For example, what germplasm went to Brazil, the Caribbean, North America, and when? What permeated the Greek and Roman Empires? How do West African sub-populations compare to the genepools in Ancient Nubia or landraces of Southeast Africa? In the USA, cowpea has been a crop plant since at least as early as 1705, apparently travelling by two separate colonial activities, one into Northern Mexico through Spanish settlement, whence it became a staple crop of Native Americans, and one into the Caribbean and Southern USA associated with the slave trade. Cowpea was prominent in the USA at the time of the Declaration of Independence, grown by Thomas Jefferson and others, and was surpassed as the number one legume crop by soybean only beginning in the 1930's. Therefore, cowpea has been tried and tested in the USA, making it poised for resurgence as a durable, protein-rich food source in the context of limited resources and climate change, as agriculture must thrive under more marginal conditions in the future. The resources developed in this project facilitate humankind's further use of cowpea as we confront the needs of a burgeoning population in the context of limited resources and climate change.
